Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE: Memory Storage by Variable-size Stable Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mechanism of memory is one the major mysteries of biology. Recent work suggests that as a result of learning synapses grow and that the size of the synapse is what stores the components of memories. The aim of the proposed work is to visualize directly this growth process in brain tissue using a newly developed super-resolution microscope, and to understand why such structures have stable size once learning has occurred. Instability would result is loss of memory, so evolution is thought to have favored ways of maximizing stability. To gain insight into the mechanism of stability, physical and computational model systems will be used. If the principles that underlie stability in the face of variable size can be understood, the outcome of this work could open the door to a new era in nanotechnology in which these principles could be utilized, leading potentially to novel solutions to problems in self-assembly. Additional contributions of this project include the organization and instruction of a course in the scientific programming language, MATLAB, in an enrichment course for students from groups under-represented in science and technology, and the opportunity for US trainees to participate in an international collaboration.

This proposal focuses on supramolecular structures that do not have fixed size but can exist in multiple different sizes, all of which are stable. Thus, if a stimulus causes the transition from one stable state to another, the structure has information storage capability (memory). The investigators termed this type of structure variable-size stable structures (VSSS). Interest in VSSS arises from two seemingly unrelated fields: neuroscience and the physics of nanostructures. The molecular basis of memory is one the most fundamental unsolved problems in neuroscience. Evidence strongly suggests that synapses grow to encode memory. Thus, memory storage in the brain appears to be a structural problem, and efforts need to be made to understand the structural principles that make memory storage possible. The project integrates cutting-edge optical microscopy with theoretical modeling. Utilizing a newly-available super-resolution microscope, the investigators will make the first effort to observe synaptic growth during synaptic plasticity in real time. The goal of the theoretical efforts is to develop a physical theory of VSSS and evaluate different models, including ones that have emerged from the study of synapses. Questions to be addressed include: (i) The importance of cooperative interactions among multiple components to generating stable yet kinetically accessible and reconfigurable assemblages. (ii) Design principles that lead to self-terminating assembly, such as growth by finite-size modules. (iii) Mechanisms by which nonequilibrium energy consumption changes the limits of VSSS. An ultimate goal is a generalized theory for nonequilibrium self-assembly capable of describing VSSS.

This project is jointly funded by the Neural Systems Cluster in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems and by the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Physics Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. We developed three methods to label synapses, so that individual synapses can be visualized as they change size and structure during the process which is believed to underlie the acquisition of a memory. We validated that these labeling methods do not interfere with synapse growth or structure.


2. Using these new labeling methods, we analyzed the rate at which the protein constituents of a synapse add to or dissociate from the synapse structure. Our experiments revealed that, in addition to the processes of protein addition/dissociation already known, there is another process (that occurs at a different rate). The dynamics of this new process suggest that, in addition to the strongly bound synapse constituents, there is another, more weakly bound constituent.


3. To further test the above findings, we developed a new way to analyze results from a technique known as fluorescent recovery after photobleaching (FRAP), which is a technique commonly used to study the rates at which proteins bind to/dissociate from structures. In particular, we identified limitations to the typical practice of fitting FRAP data with a pre-assumed model with a fixed number of parameters. We introduced a more robust fitting strategy that employs Bayesian techniques to compare different models, and automatically penalizes models which have too many adjustable parameters and therefore overfit data. The methodology provides a means to guide future experiments, by guiding the selection of time resolution (how frequently data points are collected) and duration of data collection (how long the experiment should run for).


4. We developed a new theory to explain how synapses are able to remain stable at a fixed size over the lifetime of a memory, and yet undergo constant recycling of their constituent proteins, and can change to a new stable size during acquisition of a new memory. Our theory unites results of two different experimental methodologies for visualizing synapse structures, which seemed to be in conflict with each other. In particular, these methodologies are super-resolution fluorescence microscopy, which uses a light microscope to visualize structures in real time on the nanometer scale, and electron microscopy, which uses an electron beam to visualize fixed structures at high spatial resolution. Our new model suggests that there is a simple principle which controls the stability of synapses at variable sizes:  the synapse grows in a modular fashion, meaning that groups of new subunits in a well-defined substructure add-on to or dissociate from an existing synapse. The addition or dissociation of each modular substructure is controlled by a ‘switch’; i.e. a system of biochemical reactions which can switch between two different levels of chemical concentrations in response to changes in the local environment.


5. We theoretically analyzed a number of different mechanisms by which biological systems can generate size-controlled structures through self assembly. For each mechanism, we identified a unique signature that can be identified through experiment, based on the distribution of structure sizes or the rate at which the constituent proteins recycle (measured for example by FRAP). This will enable experiments to determine what mechanism underlies a given process in a given biological system. The models also allow distinguishing between systems that undergo equilibrium self-assembly (meaning they require no energy input) and those that undergo nonequilibrium assembly (requiring energy input).
